question: Why is a specified-head boundary represented as a vertical line in a Q–h plot? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! For a Dirichlet condition, head is specified and Q varies. It often reflects external controls like large lakes that are in direct contact with the groundwater system.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. For a Dirichlet condition, the head is specified, not the flow, and the value of recharge does not influence the value of specified head.

question: Which characteristics best describe a head-dependent boundary (Robin condition)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Head-dependent flux is based on the head difference times a conductance value that controls how easily flow occurs.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Only when head in the groundwater system and boundary are equal is the flow zero — not always. Also, the head is only equal to the river stage if there is no source of water to flow out of the boundary.

question: What happens in a groundwater model if recharge is increased while keeping boundary types unchanged? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Recharge increases head and thus outflow, but groundwater system properties and boundary locations stay the same.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Recharge affects system input and outflow, but it does not alter groundwater system properties or boundary positions.

question: In which of the following cases does the Q–h plot appear as a horizontal line (i.e., when Q is represented by the y-axis)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Neumann (defined-flow) boundaries have fixed Q, so the Q–h plot is horizontal.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Horizontal Q–h lines occur when flow is fixed regardless of head — which is the case for no-flow and recharge boundaries.

question: Which statements correctly describe the influence of hydraulic conductivity (K) in a 1D groundwater model? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! K determines how easily water flows through the groundwater system, affecting head gradients, and in cases where boundaries allow through flow of groundwater higher K increases inflow and outflow, but K does not the shape of the Q–h plot at a fixed-head boundary.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. K strongly influences head gradients and flow rates in a model with boundaries that allow through flow, but not the shape of the Q–h curve at a Dirichlet boundary which is determined by the definition of a specified head boundary, not by the groundwater system parameter values.

question: In a 1D model with recharge, a no-flow boundary, and a specified head boundary, which of the following are true? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! No-flow boundaries force one-directional flow; recharge raises head, but no flow occurs at the boundary.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Q–h at no-flow is vertical (Q = 0, and h is variable) and no head-dependent exchange of water occurs there.
